text: That I will not take from a thread even to a shoelatchet , and that I will not take any thing that is thine, lest thou shouldest say, I have made Abram rich:
text_kjv: That I will not take from a thread even to a shoelatchet , and that I will not take any thing that is thine, lest thou shouldest say, I have made Abram rich:
text_niv: that I will accept nothing belonging to you, not even a thread or the thong of a sandal, so that you will never be able to say, ‘I made Abram rich.’
text_esv: that I would not take a thread or a sandal strap or anything that is yours, lest you should say, ‘I have made Abram rich.’
text_nlt: that I will not take so much as a single thread or sandal thong from what belongs to you. Otherwise you might say, ‘I am the one who made Abram rich.’
text_msg: that I'll take nothing from you, not so much as a thread or a shoestring. I'm not going to have you go around saying, 'I made Abram rich.'
text_nasb: that I will not take a thread or a sandal thong or anything that is yours, for fear you would say, 'I have made Abram rich.'
context: Genesis 14 takes place within the patriarchal narratives, specifically during Abram's (later Abraham) early journey of faith. The chapter describes a conflict between several kings in Mesopotamia and the kings of Sodom, Gomorrah, and other cities in the Jordan Valley. Abram intervenes to rescue his nephew Lot, who was taken captive during the conflict. Abram's small force defeats Chedorlaomer and his allies, a significant military victory reflecting divine favor. After the battle, Abram is met by two kings: the king of Sodom and Melchizedek, king of Salem. The king of Sodom offers Abram the spoils of war, likely including goods and captives taken from his own people and the defeated armies. The standard practice in ancient warfare allowed victors to claim such spoils as their right. The value of these spoils would have been considerable, potentially providing Abram with significant wealth and influence. The shoelatchet, literally a sandal strap, and the thread represent the smallest and seemingly insignificant items. This detail highlights the totality of Abram's refusal. Abram's earlier background, revealed later in the scriptures as coming from Ur of the Chaldees, a wealthy and sophisticated civilization, contrasts this act. He was accustomed to a certain level of comfort and possessions, making his refusal a notable sacrifice.
meaning: Abram's declaration in Genesis 14:23 is a powerful expression of his faith and integrity. His refusal of the king of Sodom's offer is not merely about material wealth; it's a deliberate act of dependence on God and a rejection of worldly recognition. Abram understood that accepting the spoils from the king of Sodom could be interpreted as receiving his prosperity from a human source, thereby diminishing God's role as the sole provider and protector. The phrase 'lest thou shouldest say, I have made Abram rich' reveals Abram's fear of diminishing God's glory. Abram recognized that true wealth and blessing came from God alone, and he was unwilling to compromise that understanding for any material gain. This is a powerful example of covenantal commitment. By refusing the king's offer, Abram reinforces his trust in God's promise to bless him and make him a great nation. He chooses obedience and faith over immediate gratification. This act foreshadows the theme of reliance on God that continues throughout Abraham's life and the subsequent narratives of Israel. Abram's decision stands in stark contrast to the values of the surrounding culture, where power and wealth were often obtained through conquest and self-promotion. He demonstrates a different way of living, one based on faith, integrity, and dependence on divine provision.
application: In today's materialistic society, Abram's example is profoundly relevant. We are constantly bombarded with messages encouraging us to seek wealth, status, and recognition. Genesis 14:23 challenges us to examine our own motivations and priorities. Are we willing to forgo opportunities for financial gain or advancement if they compromise our integrity or diminish God's glory? Abram's refusal to accept even a thread or a shoelatchet challenges us to consider the subtle ways we might compromise our values in pursuit of worldly success. It asks: What 'small things' are we willing to overlook to get ahead? We can apply this principle in various areas of our lives. In our careers, it might mean refusing to participate in unethical business practices, even if it means missing out on a promotion or bonus. In our finances, it might mean resisting the temptation to accumulate wealth through dishonest means. In our relationships, it might mean refusing to gossip or engage in other behaviors that undermine others. Abram’s example also highlights the importance of giving credit where it is due. We should actively acknowledge God's role in our successes, avoiding the temptation to take credit for things He has enabled us to achieve. This requires humility and a constant awareness of God's presence in our lives. It means understanding that our talents, opportunities, and resources are all gifts from God, to be used for His glory and the benefit of others. Finally, it is an invitation to live radically counter-cultural lives. When the dominant culture tells us to accumulate, Abram’s response urges us to resist, relying instead on the Lord's promise to meet our needs.
prayer: Heavenly Father, I come before you recognizing that all good things come from you. Forgive me for the times I have sought wealth and recognition from worldly sources, forgetting that you are my ultimate provider. Grant me the strength to resist the temptations of materialism and compromise, even in the smallest of matters. Help me to emulate Abram's unwavering faith and integrity, always giving you the glory for my successes. Instill in me a deep and abiding trust in your provision, knowing that you will never forsake those who seek you. May my life be a testament to your faithfulness and goodness, so that others may see your hand at work. In Jesus' name, Amen.

faqs.answer: Abram refused the spoils to ensure no one could claim they made him rich. He wanted to make it clear that his prosperity came solely from God's blessing and promise, preserving God's glory and demonstrating his unwavering faith.
faqs.question: Q1: Why was it so important for Abram to refuse the spoils of war?

faqs.answer: It represents the smallest and most insignificant items. Abram's refusal of even these seemingly worthless things underscores his complete rejection of worldly wealth as his source of provision. It highlights the totality of his faith.
faqs.question: Q2: What does 'a thread even to a shoelatchet' symbolize in this verse?

faqs.answer: Unlike many leaders who sought to amass wealth and power through conquest, Abram refused to exploit his victory. His actions demonstrated integrity and reliance on God, contrasting with the self-serving ambition common in that era.
faqs.question: Q3: How does Abram's response contrast with the actions of other leaders in the ancient world?

faqs.answer: Modern 'shoelatchets' could include accepting a small bribe, compromising on ethical standards for a minor gain, or taking credit for someone else's work, representing small compromises of integrity.
faqs.question: Q4: What are some examples of 'shoelatchets' in our modern lives that we might be tempted to accept?

faqs.answer: We can apply it by prioritizing integrity over profit, giving generously, avoiding debt, and acknowledging God's provision in all aspects of our finances. Seek God's guidance in all decisions.
